content:
Back on the topic of EIP-2315...

The removal of dynamic jumps I believe to be important for static analysis.  In a past life I had to do bytecode analysis/rewriting and dynamic jumps are *by far* the hardest thing to deal with.  If it weren't for dynamic jumps bytecode mutation becomes quite easy.  That is EIP-615.  I agree with the argument that 615 *should* be split into multiple smaller EIPs because it changes too much at once in a single *technical document*.  This is exactly what the author did and then they introduces the first of those EIPs to get the ball rolling.  IMO, this is a very appropriate iterative process and we should be encouraging it, not discouraging it.

author: sky.cactus
content: To <@489256758989029405> I think it is reasonable to ask "who will use this", and the answer I believe is that it will be used once dynamic jumps are removed in the future and this is a necessary change to achieve that goal.  We *could* wait and include all of the changes at once, but that is a very non-iterative process and iterative processes in software *tend* to be better.

author: sky.cactus
content: EIP-615 lays out a clear path to the removal of dynamic jumps and it can be done in steps.  Subroutines is one step, datablocks is another, static jumps is another, and finally the removal of dynamic jumps is the last.

author: Deleted User
content: I had more thoughts about this today and also I refreshed knowledge on JVM and Risk-V to understand what is going there, specifically about static/dynamic jump question. JVM instruction set is from the start with variable length opcodes, which allows to have all jump/branch offsets to be part of the instruction (immediates). In that sense, JVM is dynamic-jump free. Risk-V, on the other hand, has fixed opcode size, 4 bytes. They have branch instructions with offsets as immediates, which can be classified as static jumps, but they are limited in how far they can jump. Then there are "subroutine" jumps, `jal` and so on, these can perform long jumps, and use registers to read the jump location from. These are in effect dynamic jumps. Looking at EVM, we have most opcodes 1 byte long, and changing that would be backwards incompatible. So if we think we are stuck with 1 byte opcodes, then there is no hope to ever escape dynamic jumps, because we cannot add jump offsets to the opcodes. If that's the case, I agree with <@!683653554631868440> that the matter of static/dynamic jumps is a red herring. EVM would need to be completely redone most probably to achieve that. And more importantly, some general design direction need to be chosen.

<@456226577798135808>  wrote:

```Looking at EVM, we have most opcodes 1 byte long, and changing that would be backwards incompatible. So if we think we are stuck with 1 byte opcodes```

We are _NOT_ stuck with one byte opcodes.

Versioning is _NOT_ required for multi-byte opcodes or immediates.

We could do `JUMPSUB PUSH*<beginsub_offset>`. The program counter would be incremented to jump over the PUSH* and offsets.

Note that the `PUSH*` is never executed, it is just a guard to preserve backwards compatibility.

Another option is to break backwards compatibility once we have EIP-2327 (`BEGINDATA`).
